anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated August 31, 1956, of the Court of the Special Judge at Delhi, in Corruption Case No. 8 of 1956. R. Kalia and K. L. Arora, for the appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 202 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellants were police constables at the time of the occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.-The appellants, who were police companystables at the time of the occurrence, were companyvicted by the Special Judge of Delhi under s. 120B and s. 224/109 of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Appellants convicted by Special Judge of Delhi under sections 120B, 224/109 IPC and 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: were companyvicted by the Special Judge of Delhi under s. 120B and s. 224/109 of the Indian Penal Code and s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act  2 of 1947 . They were sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947

facts.text: Appellants sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment under s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: They were sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and to nine months rigorous imprisonment under each of the ss. 120B and 224/109 of the Indian Penal Code. 1220 The sentences of imprisonment were directed to run companycurrently.

facts.text: Appellants sentenced to nine months rigorous imprisonment under each of ss.120B and 224/109 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: and to nine months rigorous imprisonment under each of the ss. 120B and 224/109 of the Indian Penal Code. 1220 The sentences of imprisonment were directed to run companycurrently. Their appeals to the Punjab High Court were dismissed

facts.text: Sentences of imprisonment directed to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: The sentences of imprisonment were directed to run companycurrently. Their appeals to the Punjab High Court were dismissed and the present appeals are by special leave.

facts.text: Appeals to Punjab High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Their appeals to the Punjab High Court were dismissed and the present appeals are by special leave. The case of the prosecution, as stated in the charge, was that the appellants had companyspired at Delhi

facts.text: Appellants conspired at Delhi with Ram Saran Das, M.P. Khare, Nand Parkash Kapur and Murari between 6th and 16th November 1955 to bring about escape of M.P. Khare from lawful custody.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution, as stated in the charge, was that the appellants had companyspired at Delhi with Ram Saran Das, the approver, M. P. Khare, Nand Parkash Kapur and Murari between the 6th and 16th of November, 1955, to bring about the escape from lawful custody of M. P. Khare, an undertrial prisoner,

facts.text: Appellants agreed to accept Rs. 1,000 each and other pecuniary advantages as illegal gratification for escape of M.P. Khare.

anchor.surface_text: and that they had also agreed to accept Rs. 1,000 each and other pecuniary advantages as illegal gratification for rendering the escape of M. P. Khare from lawful custody and that in pursuance of the said companyspiracy they had abetted the escape of M. P. Khare

facts.text: Appellants abetted the escape of M.P. Khare from lawful custody.

anchor.surface_text: they had abetted the escape of M. P. Khare and that they had accepted the illegal gratification from Nand Parkash Kapur. It is clear from the findings of the companyrts below that M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody

facts.text: Appellants accepted illegal gratification from Nand Parkash Kapur.

anchor.surface_text: and that they had accepted the illegal gratification from Nand Parkash Kapur. It is clear from the findings of the companyrts below that M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody and the appellants had enabled him to do so

facts.text: M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the findings of the companyrts below that M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody and the appellants had enabled him to do so and that they had received money as illegal gratification

facts.text: Appellants enabled M.P. Khare to escape from lawful custody.

anchor.surface_text: that M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody and the appellants had enabled him to do so and that they had received money as illegal gratification for the part they had played in enabling M.P. Khare to escape

facts.text: Appellants received money as illegal gratification for enabling M.P. Khare to escape.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellants had enabled him to do so and that they had received money as illegal gratification for the part they had played in enabling M.P. Khare to escape from lawful custody.

arguments.claim: Court of Special Judge deemed Court of Session for CrPC purposes under s.8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 3  of the Criminal Law Amendment Act of 1952 it is expressly stated that for the purposes of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Court of Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session trying cases without a jury or without the aid of assessors.

arguments.claim: High Court exercises powers as if Special Judge were Court of Session under s.9 Criminal Law Amendment Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 of that Act provides for an appeal from the Court of the Special Judge to the High Court and states that the High Court may exercise, as far as they may be applicable, all the powers conferred by Chapters XXXI and XXXII of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898,

arguments.claim: District Magistrate had authority to tender pardon under s.337 CrPC as Special Judge is Court of Session in law

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we are of the opinion that although the offence was triable exclusively by the Court of the Special Judge the District Magistrate had authority to tender a pardon under s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as the court of the Special Judge was, in law, a Court of Session.

arguments.claim: s.8(2) Criminal Law Amendment Act grants Special Judge pardon power but does not deprive District Magistrate of s.337 CrPC power

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 2  of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952, the Special Judge has also been granted power to tender pardon. The conferment of this power on the Special Judge in no way deprives the District Magistrate of his power to grant a pardon under s. 337 of the Code.

arguments.claim: Irregularity in charge framing cured by s.537 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the irregularity committed, in this case, was 1222 cured by the provisions of s. 537 of the Code. It is to be noticed that it was urged before the Special Judge that separate charges should have been framed

arguments.claim: Appellants not prejudiced by charge form; objection abandoned

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be urged that the appellants were prejudiced by the charge as framed. Indeed, the Advocate for the appellants abandoned this objection and there is nothing in the High Courts judgment to show that this contention was again raised.

arguments.claim: Failure to hold test identification parade does not make identification evidence inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: As for the test identification parade, it is true that no test identification parade was held. The appellants were known to the police officials who had deposed against the appellants and the only persons who did not know them before were the persons who gave evidence of association,

arguments.claim: Mela Ram and Shiv Parshad not accomplices

anchor.surface_text: Points 3, 4 and 5 may be disposed of at the outset. We have examined the evidence of Mela Ram and Shiv Parshad and find nothing in their evidence which establishes them as accomplices.

arguments.claim: Courts below entitled to believe prosecution witnesses; no material to take different view

anchor.surface_text: As to the reliability of these witnesses the courts below were entitled to believe them and nothing of any consequence has been placed before us to convince us to take a different view from that taken by the courts below.

holdings.text: Prosecution witnesses Mela Ram (PW 6) and Shiv Parshad (PW 7) were not accomplices.

anchor.surface_text: Points 3, 4 and 5 may be disposed of at the outset. We have examined the evidence of Mela Ram and Shiv Parshad and find nothing in their evidence which establishes them as accomplices.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examined evidence and found nothing establishing them as accomplices; courts below entitled to believe them with no contrary material warranting interference.

holdings.text: Failure to hold test identification parade does not render identification evidence inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: As for the test identification parade, it is true that no test identification parade was held. The appellants were known to the police officials who had deposed against the appellants and the only persons who did not know them before were the persons who gave evidence of association,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Holding test ID prudent but not mandatory; weight of identification evidence for courts of fact; no reassessment absent exceptional grounds.

holdings.text: Irregularity in framing single charge instead of separate charges under s.233 CrPC was cured by s.537 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the irregularity committed, in this case, was 1222 cured by the provisions of s. 537 of the Code. It is to be noticed that it was urged before the Special Judge that separate charges should have been framed

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.537 cures procedural irregularities absent miscarriage of justice; objection raised but abandoned before Special Judge.

holdings.text: Appellants were not prejudiced by the form of the charge as framed.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be urged that the appellants were prejudiced by the charge as framed. Indeed, the Advocate for the appellants abandoned this objection and there is nothing in the High Courts judgment to show that this contention was again raised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advocate abandoned objection before Special Judge and did not pursue in High Court; cannot raise at Supreme Court stage.

holdings.text: Challenge to s.120B IPC conviction on grounds of no sanction under s.196A CrPC is academic and cannot be raised at this stage.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the second point, even if it is assumed that the offence alleged against the appellants does not come under s. 224 of the Indian Penal Code, but under s. 222 of the Indian Penal Code, it has to be remembered that this would be of academic interest in this case,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Academic if s.5(2) PCA conviction upheld; sanction issue not raised at trial or High Court; question of fact not entertainable now.

holdings.text: District Magistrate had authority to tender pardon under s.337 CrPC to approver Ram Saran Das as Court of Special Judge deemed Court of Session under s.8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 3  of the Criminal Law Amendment Act of 1952 it is expressly stated that for the purposes of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Court of Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session trying cases without a jury or without the aid of assessors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.8(3) deems Special Judge as Court of Session for CrPC purposes; concurrent jurisdiction with Special Judge under s.337 proviso and s.8(2); DM empowered even pre-commitment.

holdings.text: Conferment of pardon power on Special Judge under s.8(2) Criminal Law Amendment Act does not deprive District Magistrate of power under s.337 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 2  of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952, the Special Judge has also been granted power to tender pardon. The conferment of this power on the Special Judge in no way deprives the District Magistrate of his power to grant a pardon under s. 337 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express deprivation; concurrent powers contemplated by CrPC ss.337,338.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 3  of the Criminal Law Amendment Act of 1952 it is expressly stated that for the purposes of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Court of Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session trying cases without a jury or without the aid of assessors.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 2  of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952, the Special Judge has also been granted power to tender pardon. The conferment of this power on the Special Judge in no way deprives the District Magistrate of his power to grant a pardon under s. 337 of the Code.

There seems to us, therefore, numbersubstance in the submission made that the District Magistrate had number authority to tender a pardon to Ram Saran Das, the approver, and companysequently the approvers evidence was inadmissible.
